metadata.title: Glycomic analysis of host-response reveals high mannose as a key mediator of influenza severity

affiliation.institution: University of Pittsburgh School of Medicine

body_text.text: Influenza virus infections cause ~290,000-645,000 deaths (1) and 3-5 million 33 cases of severe illness annually worldwide (2). Viral infection begins in the upper 34 respiratory tract. It can lead to airway inflammation in the lungs and, in severe cases, 35
pneumonia. The molecular mechanisms that underlie disparate outcomes of mild, 36 moderate, and severe illness are currently unknown. 37

Glycosylation within the human host plays a critical role in influenza biology 38 Studies of influenza in model organisms, such as mice, commonly use strains 50 of the virus adapted to the sialic acid receptors prevalent in the upper respiratory 51 tract of these hosts (i.e. α-2,3-linked sialosides), which differ from α-2,6-sialosides 52 found in the human respiratory tract. Ferrets, however, have a similar glycan 53 distribution in their respiratory system to humans, i.e. α-2,6-linked sialic acids and 54 low levels of N-glycolyl sialosides in the upper respiratory tract. This makes them a 55 more representative model for human biology, enabling the use of un-adapted 56 human strains of influenza (5). 57

Here, we ask whether glycosylation might play a role in the outcome of 58 influenza virus infection. We analyzed ferret host response in the lung to the 2009 59 pandemic H1N1 (H1N1pdm09) influenza virus using our lectin microarray 60 technology (6-8). This H1N1 strain caused an estimated 150,000-580,000 deaths 61 worldwide in the first 12 months of circulation, with wide variation in outcomes among 62 controls. In contrast, ferrets with mild infections displayed a smaller increase in high 123 mannose levels (~12-19%, dependent on lectin). 124

Overall, our lectin microarray data argues that although we see changes in 125 sialic acids with infection, they have no correlation with severity. Rather, high 126 mannose, an epitope not typically associated with influenza pathogenesis, appears 127 to directly correlate with severity. ferrets. In general, we observed a correlation between damage to the lung, as 137 defined by consolidation and inflammatory cell infiltrate, and staining with the high 138 mannose binding lectin HHL (Fig. 2a) . In normal lung, HHL staining was confined to 139 the bronchiole epithelium and basement membrane. In contrast, in infected and 140 consolidated lung tissues we observed binding to compacted alveolar spaces and 141 bronchial plugs. We also observed binding to inflammatory cells and sloughed 142 bronchial epithelium. We observe a strong correlation between HHL staining and the 143 alveolar severity score, which reflects alveolar damage and inflammation caused by 144 the infection (Fig. 2b) . Overall, our data shows that high mannose is associated with 145 both direct damage to the lungs, observed by histology, and overall illness levels, 146 observed by weight loss. To examine whether glycomic changes in the host occur early or late in 156 influenza pathogenesis, we performed a time-course analysis where infected ferrets 157 were sacrificed at days 1, 3, 5, 8, and 14 (n=12 for days 1-3, n=8 for day 5, n=19 for 158 day 8, n=8 for day 14, for a total of 59 ferrets). We analyzed 2 lung punch biopsies 159 per ferret. The time course experiments and our previously discussed analysis were 160 performed concurrently and analyzed on the same set of arrays. Thus, data for day 161 8 ferrets and control (day 0) samples are the same as in Figure 1a . High mannose, which correlates to severity at day 8, was strongly induced in 180 some ferrets at day 1 (Fig. 3a) . Again, we observed a strong increase in high mannose in response to 208 viral infection (Fig. 4b) . Infection of A549 cells with other influenza strains 209 (H1N1pdm09, H3N2, influenza B, Fig. 4c) , also resulted in an increase in high 210 mannose, indicating that the response is not strain specific. 211

Given that high mannose is a precursor in the N-glycan pathway, a question 212 that arises is whether high mannose could act as an independent signal without 213 impacting complex N-glycan levels. Recent studies have shown that the trimming 214 mannosidases, MAN1A1 and MAN1A2 can be independently deleted without 215 impacting complex N-glycans (29, 30). In addition, both enzymes are predicted to be 216 highly regulated by miRNA (31), and miRNA downregulating MAN1A2 increased 217 high mannose without decreasing core fucose, a marker of complex N-glycans (11). 218

To test this more directly, we performed lectin microarray analysis of A549 cells 219 infected with PR8 ( Fig. 5a, Supplemental Fig. 10 ). In line with our observation in 220 ferret lungs and our microscopy data, we again observed an increase in high 221 mannose (GRFT, SVN, HHL, UDA). However, we did not observe a corresponding 222 immune response, and viral stability (33). Glycosylation of NA is essential for the 233 enzyme activity (33). M2, a small transmembrane protein of about 11 KD, is at 10-234 100 fold lower abundance than HA on the virus surface and has a putative N-235 glycosylation site at which glycosylation is not commonly observed (33-36). To 236 determine whether the increase in high mannose was due to influenza virus 237 glycoproteins or to changes in glycosylation of host proteins, we performed lectin 238 blot analysis in tandem with Western blot analysis of HA and NA, the major influenza 239 virus glycoproteins (Fig. 5b, Supplemental Fig. 11 ). Upon infection, we detect 240 increased levels of high mannose across multiple proteins, both influenza and host, 241 as determined by HHL binding. We observed a strong increase in high mannose for 242 a band correlating to NA (indicated by arrows, Fig. 5b) . Quantitation of the lectin 243 blot, excluding presumed HA and NA proteins, reveals a 120% increase in HHL 244 binding, indicating a major increase in high mannose on host proteins. The use of high mannose by the cell, as a type of 327 damage or distress signal, makes sense as it is not detected at the cell surface on 328 most cell types, but is recognized by a significant number of innate immune lectins, 329

including MBL2 (Fig. 7) (12). In addition, high mannose has the potential for 330 independent regulation from the complex N-glycan pool (Fig. 5a) (11, 29-31) . Taken 331 together, our work provides a new mechanism that could explain the observation 332 that both UPR activation and MBL2 levels directly associate with severity of outcome 333 from influenza infection (13, 18, 19) . 334

A picture is emerging in which high mannose could act as a signal to our 335 immune system through MBL2 (and potentially other mannose-binding lectins) to 336 clear damaged and infected cells. FIGREF0.text: . Influenza virus infection is initiated by adhesion of viral hemagglutinin (HA) to 39 glycans containing α-2,6-linked sialic acids on the human host epithelial cells. Viral 40 propagation requires cleavage of these sialic acid residues by the influenza virus 41 enzyme neuraminidase (NA), the current target of some anti-viral therapies (4). Due 42 to their role in influenza biology, glycans have been studied in influenza almost 43 exclusively in the context of binding to sialic acids. However, whether sialic acid plays 44 a role in the severity of the host response to influenza virus infection is unknown. In 45 addition, there are currently no systematic studies on the response of the host 46 glycome to influenza virus infection. Whether host glycosylation (e.g. sialylation and 47 other motifs) is modulated upon infection, and what impact these modifications could 48 have on the severity of influenza virus induced disease have not been examined. 49

FIGREF1.text: Shows High Mannose Associates with Alveolar Severity 130 As the influenza virus infection progresses to a more severe state, it moves 131 from the upper respiratory tract into the alveolar cells of the lungs. The earliest 132 responses are seen in the infected airway or lung alveolar epithelial cells. These 133 cells become damaged, leading to lung dysfunction and pneumonia (25). To more 134 directly observe whether high mannose levels are associated with damage in ferret 135 lung, we next performed lectin histology on inflated lung tissue from day 8 infected 136

FIGREF2.text: High mannose is induced early in the course of infection. 149Viral titers in the lungs reach high levels early in the course of influenza 150 infection and decline significantly by day 8, with few residual viral particles by day 14 151

FIGREF3.text: Severity was 162 determined by weight loss for ferrets sacrificed at days 8 and 14. Severity cannot be 163 determined at earlier time points as the weight loss nadir has not been reached at 164 days 1-5. Lung punch biopsies were analyzed as previously described. The heatmap 165 for the overall analysis is shown in Supplemental Fig. 5. 166 Time course analysis revealed dynamic changes in host glycans upon 167 infection. Levels of α-2,6-linked sialic acid increased upon infection, plateauing at 168 day 3 (~31% change), before decreasing to baseline levels by day 8 (Supplemental 169 Fig. 6a). This dynamic change in host glycans may play a role in propagating the 170 infection as α-2,6-sialosides are the host receptor for human influenza virus, 171including H1N1pdm09. Levels of α-2,3-linked sialic acid declined rapidly by day 1 172 (~22%) and were only partially recovered at day 8(Supplemental Fig. 6b). Levels 173 of GM1 dramatically increased early in the course of infection (day 1, ~72%), 174 perhaps due to increased viral budding from lipid rafts. These levels rapidly 175 decreased by day 3, in line with decreased viral titers in the lung tissue 176 (SupplementalFigs. 5 & 6c). Although these glycomic changes probably play a role 177 in influenza pathogenesis, we cannot determine whether they influence severity at 178 the early time points. 179

For our initial experiments, we used the adenocarcinoma A549 cell 193 line, a common cell line in influenza research (26, 27), which derives from human 194 alveolar basal epithelia. In brief, cells were infected with A/Puerto 195 Rico/8/1934(H1N1) (PR8), an H1N1 strain commonly used in cell culture 196 experiments. After 24 h, cells were fixed and stained for influenza nucleoprotein 197(anti-influenza antibody, green) and high mannose(HHL, red, Fig. 4a). We observed 198strong induction of high mannose in infected cells. Treatment of cells with Endo H, 199an endoglycosidase specific for high mannose and hybrid structures (28), abolished 200 lectin staining, as did treatment with methyl mannose(Supplemental Fig. 7), 201confirming the induction of high mannose upon infection. This epitope is induced 202 both internally and at the cell surface, as confirmed by deconvolution microscopy 203 (SupplementalFig. 8). High mannose was observed to increase in internal 204 structures early in the infection (8h,Supplemental Fig. 9) before migrating to the 205 cell surface. FIGREF6.text: is Induced via the IRE1/XBP1 Pathway 249 Recent work provides evidence for the involvement of the unfolded protein 250 response (UPR) in determining influenza severity. Influenza virus activates the IRE1 251 arm of the UPR pathway, inducing the active form of the transcription factor XBP1 252 (XBP1s) (37). Influenza severity and lung injury in mouse models directly correlate 253 with the degree of induction of this pathway (13). Recent studies have shown that 254 activation of XBP1s in cells can alter glycosylation in a cell type dependent manner, 255 providing a potential link between influenza infection and the observed changes in 256 host glycosylation (38, 39). FIGREF8.text: Immune Activator MBL2 Recognizes Infected Cells via High Mannose. 273 Currently, there is an emerging consensus that over-activation of the innate 274 immune response may be a dominant cause of lung injury and influenza severity 275 (20, 25). Carbohydrate recognition plays a significant role in innate immunity 276 proteins A and D (SP-A/D) (12, 42). Innate immune lectins are thought 280 to protect against infection through recognition of foreign pathogens. We focused 281 our attention on MBL2. MBL2 binds influenza viral particles and was originally 282 ascribed a protective role (43). However, knockout of MBL2 in mouse mitigated the 283 severity of influenza infection, rather than increasing viral load as originally theorized 284 (18). Upon binding, MBL2 activates the complement cascade and corresponding 285 inflammatory response (44). A recent study on critically ill patients infected with 286 H1N1pdm09 virus showed a strong correlation between levels of MBL2 in the blood 287 and patient death (19). In addition, schizophrenics and multiple sclerosis patients, 288 both have high levels of MBL2 and unusually high death rates from influenza and 289 pneumonia (45-48). These studies strongly suggest that MBL2 plays a determining 290 role in the severity of response, but how this occurs is unknown. 291 MBL2 recognizes several glycan epitopes including Lewis structures (14, 15), 292 high mannose (16), yeast mannans (17) and fucose (15). Given that high mannose 293 is a ligand for MBL2, we wanted to test whether MBL2 would recognize influenza 294virus-infected human cells. We incubated infected and control A549 cells with 295 recombinant human MBL2 and examined binding by fluorescence microscopy(Fig. 296 7). Uninfected A549 cells were not recognized by MBL2. In contrast, infected cells 297 were strongly recognized by the innate immune lectin. This data is in keeping with 298 previous work that demonstrated complement-dependent lysis of influenza-infected 299 hamster cells mediated through binding of guinea pig mannan-binding lectin (49).

FIGREF10.text: 311 Current studies of these interactions almost exclusively focus on their roles in 312 invasion or on innate immune lectin recognition of pathogen glycans (50). In contrast, 313 little is known about change in the host glycome upon pathogen invasion and how 314 this might impact disease progression. 315 Herein, we use a ferret model of influenza virus infection in tandem with our 316 lectin microarray technology (6, 8) to study the host response to the 2009 H1N1 317 influenza virus and its relationship to disease progression. Our data suggest that 318 induction of high mannose upon influenza virus infection is a key mediator of 319 severity. Based on our work and the current literature, we hypothesize that activation 320 of the unfolded protein response (UPR) upon influenza infection turns on expression 321 of high mannose, which is then recognized by the innate immune lectin MBL2, 322

Our work provides a potential new pathway for 344 intervention in influenza virus infection that could spur the development of therapies 345 that would make influenza virus-induced disease no more deadly than the common 346 cold. 347 348 METHODS 349 Influenza virus and infection of ferrets. Fitch ferrets (Mustela putorius furo, 350 female) were obtained from Triple F Farms (Sayre) and verified as negative for 351 antibodies to circulating influenza A (H1N1 and H3N2) and B viruses. Adult ferrets 352 were defined as 6-12 months of age. Ferrets were pair housed in stainless steel 353 cages (Shor-Line) containing Sani-Chips laboratory animal bedding (P.J. Murphy 354 Forest Products) and provided with food and fresh water ad libitum. Ferrets were 355 administered intranasally the H1N1pdm09 virus, A/California/07/2009, at a dose of 356 10 6 PFU. The animals were monitored daily for weight loss and disease symptoms 357 including elevated temperature, low activity level, sneezing, and nasal discharge. 358 Animals were randomly assigned to be sacrificed at day 1, 3, 5, 8, or 14 post-359 infection (DPI) or euthanized if their clinical condition (e.g., loss of >20% body 360 weight) required it. Blood was collected from anesthetized ferrets via the subclavian 361 vena cava post-infection. Serum was harvested and frozen at -20 ± 5°C.
